Award.AwardTitle: Dissecting the TOR Kinase Pathway in Plants: Linking the Stress Signals to Growth
Award.AbstractNarration: Crop productivity is directly affected by environmental conditions and stresses such as drought and salinity significantly reduce yield. An improvement in a plant''s ability to withstand environmental stress is of fundamental importance, not only for US agriculture, but also in context of the emerging problem of global warming. Plants must optimize growth under nutritional limitations and stress to complete their life cycles. The Target of Rapamycin (TOR) kinase system is considered to be a central regulator of stress and nutritional signals in higher organisms. How these signals are prioritized and integrated to control protein synthesis (translation) and gene expression (transcription) is not well understood in any organism. Recent research in the PI''s laboratory has identified all major components of this pathway in plants and has demonstrated that an osmotic stress signal is controlled by this pathway via phosphorylation of one of the ribosomal proteins that controls protein synthesis. In addition, preliminary evidence indicates that plant hormones may also affect the TOR kinase pathway, thus providing a new approach for understanding how growth is regulated under stress. The goal of this newly funded research is to find a molecular link between the regulation of translation and transcription (particularly, ribosomal RNA) machineries in plants undergoing stress and thus provide insights into how plants acclimatize and adapt to a given environment. During the course of this research, graduate and undergraduate students will be trained and international collaborations will be forged.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plants encounter environmental stress throughout their life and plant productivity depends upon the integrated growth in response to various stress signals. Target of rapamycin (TOR) is a central regulator of stress responses and cell growth, via controlling translation and transcription machineries in eukaryotic cells. Its importance in plants is even more significant since plants have to deal directly with the environment to control their growth. We had earlier demonstrated a functional TOR kinase pathway in plants that responds to osmotic stress (drought and salinity) signals controlling phosphorylation of the ribosomal protein S6 (RPS6). During this grant support we demonstrated that the C-terminal domain of Arabidopsis TOR interacts with the yeast homolog of LST8 gene. We identified two LST8 genes in Arabidopsis, mutation in one of them was found to be lethal indicating the importance of this gene. The plant homolog of LST8.2 complements yeast mutation in lst8 gene indicating it’s functional conservation. Expression of both LST8.1 and 8.2 is affected by auxin treatment and under such a treatment  s6K is additionally phosphorylated at both amino and carboxy domains.

 We further demonstrated that RPS6 has a novel function in plants by controlling transcription of rRNA via an epigenetic mechanism its interaction with a histone deacetylase , AtHD2B.  Both RPS6 and HD2B were localized in the nucleolus where they are shown to interact with the rRNA gene promoter.  This interaction between RPS6 and AtHD2B may play an important role in linking TOR signaling to rDNA transcription in plants. Protoplasts over-expressing both AtHD2B and RPS6 exhibited down-regulation of pre-18S rRNA synthesis with concomitant decrease in some of the ribosomal proteins transcription. This study suggested a new paradigm for controlling rDNA transcription in plants, in which TOR may be involved in an epigenetic silencing of the rDNA transcription via its downstream signaling component RPS6, and this mechanism involves HD2B. Such an interaction can provide a direct link between stress signals and the regulation of translation and transcription (particularly rDNA) machineries controlling plant growth.

 

The broad impact of this study is that it allows us to understand how plant translation and transcription machineries may be regulated in response to environment and allow growth to occur, which affects plant productivity and adaptation to the changing environment. In particular it sheds light on how nucleolar dominance is regulated in hybrids where one set of rRNA genes are transcribed while the set of genes inherited from the other parent are silenced. Since bulk of the transcript in a cell is rRNA, understanding the regulation of this machinery is extremely important for plant growth.
